resources.string: Learning the basics of scales is one of the most important concepts in learning to jam along with your friends, favorite artists, and backing tracks. If you know what scale a song is in, you can easily play along!

Before diving into learning scales, you should have a basic understanding musical notes. Traditional music consists of 12 notes, or semitones - A, A#, B, C, C#, D, D#, E, F, F#, G, and G#. Each note is a half step, or semitone, away from the next note.
A whole step is two semitones away. Let\'s look at an example. If we start at A, we see that A# is a half step or semitone away. B is a whole step, or two semitones, away.
Scales are defined by their KEY and TYPE. The key of a scale is determined by the root note. If your root note is C, you are playing a C scale.
The type of scale is defined by the distance between each note in the scale, and drastically changes the way the music sounds. Let\'s explore this concept a bit.
For example, major scales, which produce a happy sound, start with the root note and go up by a whole step, whole step, half step, whole step, whole step, whole step, and half step back to the root.
Minor scales, which produce a more somber sound, start with the root note, go up by a whole step, half step, whole step, whole step, half step, whole step, and finally a whole step back to the root.
